recommendations: Prioritize a Ventilation/Perfusion (V/Q) scan for suspected Pulmonary Embolism (PE) given the patient's severe CKD (eGFR 22) and hypotension (MAP 57), avoiding iodinated contrast.

If CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) is absolutely essential and non-contrast alternatives are insufficient, implement aggressive pre-hydration with isotonic saline (if no contraindications like heart failure), use iso-osmolar, low-iodine concentration contrast, and administer the minimum effective volume. Correction of hyperkalemia (K+ 5.8 mEq/L) must be prioritized before contrast administration.
Consider bedside transthoracic echocardiography as an alternative to assess for right heart strain and rule out massive PE in the setting of hemodynamic instability, avoiding contrast entirely.
If CTPA is performed, a low-dose, non-contrast CT chest protocol for lung cancer screening should NOT be selected as it is inappropriate for acute PE evaluation.
rationale: Patient has Stage 4 CKD (eGFR 22) and significant hypotension (MAP 57), increasing risk of CIN and hemodynamic decompensation with contrast.
Critical hyperkalemia (K+ 5.8 mEq/L) requires urgent management before contrast administration.
V/Q scan is the preferred alternative to CTPA in patients with severe renal dysfunction and hemodynamic instability, as it avoids iodinated contrast.
Aggressive renal protection strategies are mandatory if contrast-enhanced imaging is pursued.
Low-dose screening CT protocols are not suitable for acute diagnostic imaging of PE.
Bedside echocardiography offers a contrast-free assessment for PE and cardiac strain.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.
protocol_selection.rationale_for_selection: This protocol is indicated for the patient's symptoms. However, its use is highly cautioned due to severe CKD and hypotension. If chosen, stringent renal protection measures and hyperkalemia management are imperative, and alternative modalities like V/Q scan should be considered first.
